title: MARKET SNAPSHOT: Dow Up Led By Intel But Mixed Earnings Restrain Other U.S. Stock Indexes
text:
By Mark DeCambre, MarketWatch , Clive McKeef

Amazon's shares down 3% after late-Thursday results

The Dow Jones Industrial Average was up Friday morning, boosted by a jump in Intel stock after earnings beat estimates, but weaker-than-expected results from Amazon restrained the other U.S. stock indexes as the busiest week of the third quarter corporate earnings reporting season winds down.

Geopolitical risks were also a concern with the European Union debating another delay to Brexit and China requesting import tariff relief before buying more U.S. agricultural products.

How are major indexes faring?

The Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 94 points or 0.3% at 26,899 while the benchmark S&P 500 index was up 5 points or 0.2% at 3,015, and the Nasdaq Composite was up 21 points or 0.3% at 8,207.

On Thursday (link), the Dow closed 28.42 points, or 0.11%, lower, at 26,805.53, with a decline in shares of Post-it maker 3M weighing on the index. The S&P 500 index , meanwhile, gained 5.77 points to 3,010.29, while the Nasdaq Composite Index added 66 points, or 0.81%, at 8,185.80.

For the week, the S&P 500 is on track to post a 0.8% weekly gain, the Nasdaq is poised for a 1.8% weekly rise while the Dow is set for a more modest 0.1% gain, as of Thursday's close.

What's driving the market?

Corporate earnings results remain the catalyst for the stock market this week, with earnings from Intel and Amazon.com the focus.

Intel (INTC) shares rose after better-than-expected earnings and revenue but Amazon (AMZN) disappointed investors with its third-quarter results (link)sending the stock down,

More than 38% of S&P 500 companies posted quarter earnings for the third quarter thus far, according to FactSet. Of those companies, 78% have beaten analyst expectations.

See: Intel stock shoots higher but one key number has analysts worried (link)

"We expect the trend in earnings results to be similar to previous quarters, where consensus reduced estimates into the reporting season, only to be revised higher as the results were out," J.P. Morgan Cazenove analyst Mislav Matejka wrote. "EPS estimates for the third quarter have now fallen below Q2 2019 delivered EPS. This is way too conservative, in our view."

See: Amazon earnings miss is the price of growth, analysts say (link)

Investors also are closely following developments related to Britain's exit from the European Union and the status of U.S. - China trade talks as global economic growth slows.

French President Emmanuel Macron blocked the EU's attempt to delay Brexit for three months (link), but the European Commission said work on this would "continue in the coming days".

Meanwhile, there is some doubt that a substantive U.S. - China trade agreement can be finalized Top U.S. and Chinese trade officials will discuss plans on Friday for China to buy more U.S. farm products, but in return, Beijing will request cancellation of some planned and existing U.S. tariffs on Chinese imports, people briefed on the talks told Reuters (link).

In U.S. economic news, the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index fell to 95.5 in October, from 96.0. "The economy is still in a good place consumers feel for now," MUFG chief economist Chris Rupkey said. "The consumer is more than willing to go it alone if necessary when it comes to the heavy lifting of the economy that is required for growth as business investment spending weakens due to the uncertainty caused by trade war tensions."

Which stocks are in focus?

Intel Corp. (INTC) shares rose 7% after the chip maker raised its outlook for the year (link)on Thursday evening after it posted an increase in third-quarter earnings.

Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) dropped 3% on Friday after the tech giant reported a 26% fall in profit (link) late Thursday as it invested heavily to speed up shipping times.

Verizon Communications Inc. (VZ) stock gained after an earnings beat (link). (link) The telecommunications giant added new phone subscribers and net income attributable to Verizon was $5.19 billion, up from $4.92 billion a year earlier. Quarterly revenue edged up slightly to $32.9 billion from $32.6 billion a year ago.

Boeing Co.'s (BA) 737 MAX was blamed formally in the Lion Air fatal nose dive (link)into the Java Sea nearly a year ago by Indonesia investigators.

How are other markets performing?

Treasury yields were little changed on Friday as a lack of fresh developments on Brexit and U.S-China trade drew investors' attention to next week's Federal Reserve meeting, where another quarter point rate cut is expected. The 10-year Treasury note yield was up 0.4 basis point to 1.770%,

Oil futures drifted into negative territory Friday, but remained on track for weekly gains as concerns over supply appeared to take over the spotlight from longer-term worries over global economic growth and the outlook for crude demand. West Texas Intermediate crude for December on the New York Mercantile Exchange was off 10 cents, or 0.2%, at $56.13 a barrel, but was on track for a 4.4% weekly advance after ending Thursday at a nearly one-month high.

Gold futures extended a gain above a key $1,500 price on Friday and looked poised to carve out a fresh near-term settlement high as investors positioned for more easing from global central banks, which could add further support for bullion. December gold on Comex gained $9.20, or 0.6%, to $1,514.20 an ounce, which would mark the highest close for the most-active contract since Oct. 4, if it holds, according to FactSet data, following a 0.6% gain for the metal on Thursday.

European stocks edged lower on Friday. After closing Thursday at its highest level since Jan. 29, 2018, the Stoxx Europe 600 declined 0.12% to 396.91.

In Asia, Japan's Nikkei gave up early gains after Trade Minister Isshu Sugawara resigned (link)after just a month on the job.

Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index fell 0.4%, while the Shanghai Composite slipped 0.2% and the smaller-cap Shenzhen Composite rose slightly.

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

October 25, 2019 10:41 ET (14:41 GMT)
